info.headline: Hurricane Local Statement issued July 02 at 10:59PM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: This product covers southeast North Carolina and northeast South Carolina **Colin Weakens to a Tropical Depression** NEW INFORMATION --------------- * CHANGES TO WATCHES AND WARNINGS: - All watches and warnings have been canceled * CURRENT WATCHES AND WARNINGS: - None * STORM INFORMATION: - About 10 miles north of Wilmington NC - 34.4N 77.8W - Storm Intensity 35 mph - Movement Northeast or 55 degrees at 7 mph SITUATION OVERVIEW ------------------ Tropical Depression Colin has continued to weaken and is no longer capable of producing tropical storm force winds. Showers have decreased significantly as what is left of the system drifts eastward across southeast NC overnight and into Sunday. Despite the system weakening, hazardous marine conditions will continue. Rough surf and rip currents are likely to continue along the NC coast through Sunday morning. POTENTIAL IMPACTS ----------------- * FLOODING RAIN: No additional impacts are anticipated at this time across southeast North Carolina. * WIND: No additional impacts are anticipated at this time across southeast North Carolina. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS ---------------------------------- Visitors in the area should listen for the name of the city and county in which you are staying for local news updates. Pay attention for instructions from local authorities and use caution when traveling on wet roadways. * ADDITIONAL SOURCES OF INFORMATION: - For information on appropriate preparations see ready.gov - For information on creating an emergency plan see getagameplan.org - For additional disaster preparedness information see redcross.org NEXT UPDATE ----------- As it pertains to this event...this will be the last local statement issued by the National Weather Service in Wilmington NC regarding the effects of tropical cyclone hazards upon the area.
